properties.Name: MortgageLoanSummary
properties.Description:
A legal document that pledges property to a creditor for the repayment of the loan, and is the term used to describe the loan itself. 

Some states use the term First Trust Deeds to refer to mortgage loans.

Columns.Name: CreditGrantorId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Credit Grantor.

Columns.Name: MortgageLoanAccountNumber
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Columns.Name: PropertyLegalDescription
Columns.Description: A property description, recognized by law that is sufficient to locate and identify the property without oral testimony.

Columns.Name: MortgageLoanAmount
Columns.Description: The amount of the mortgage loan.

Columns.Name: PrincipalAmount
Columns.Description: The amount  owed on a loan, excluding interest.

Columns.Name: OriginalPrincipalBalanceAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of principal owed on a mortgage before any payments are made.

Columns.Name: LockPeriodDays
Columns.Description: The period, expressed in days, during which a lender will guarantee a rate.

Columns.Name: DownPaymentAmount
Columns.Description: The part of the purchase price, which the buyer pays in cash and does not finance with a mortgage

Columns.Name: DepositAmount
Columns.Description: A sum of money given to bind the sale of real estate, or a sum of money given to ensure payment or an advance of funds in the processing of a loan.

Columns.Name: FinanceChargeAmount
Columns.Description: The total dollar amount your loan will cost you. It includes all interest payments for the life of the loan, any interest paid at closing, your origination fee and any other charges paid to the lender and/or broker. Appraisal, credit report and title search fees are not included in the finance charge calculation.

Columns.Name: EarnestMoneyAmount
Columns.Description: The deposit money given to the seller or his agent by the potential buyer upon the signing of the agreement of sale to show that he is serious about buying the house. If the sale goes through, the earnest money is applied against the down payment. If the sale does not go through, the earnest money will be forfeited or lost unless the binder or offer to purchase expressly provides that it is refundable.

Columns.Name: AmortizationTerm
Columns.Description: The amount of time required to amortize the mortgage loan. The amortization term is expressed as a number of months.

Columns.Name: GracePeriod
Columns.Description: A time allowed, usually 15 days, for making late payments without a penalty

Columns.Name: CashOutAmount
Columns.Description: A loan transaction in which the borrower receives funds at the time of closing.

Columns.Name: LoanToValueRatio
Columns.Description:
The loan-to-value ratio (LTV) is the original loan amount divided by the lower of the sales price or the appraised value.

The relationship between the amount of the mortgage loan and the appraised value of the property expressed as a percentage. A LTV ratio of 90 means that a borrower is borrowing 90% of the value of the property and paying 10% as a down payment. For purchases, the value of the property is assumed to be the purchase price, for refinances the value is determined by an appraisal.

Columns.Name: SellerProvidedFundsAmount
Columns.Description: A loan made by the owner of property to the purchaser to cover part or all of the sales price. While common with both residential and commercial real estate, seller financing, or owner financing as it is also called, becomes a very popular means of "making the deal work" when interest rates are high. During such times, the purchaser who is unable to qualify for a loan from a traditional lender often turns to the seller and makes an offer to purchase contingent upon seller financing.

Columns.Name: SellerProvidedFundsDescription
Columns.Description: A description of the terms and conditions associated with the seller-provided funds.

Columns.Name: InitialBorrowerPaymentRate
Columns.Description: The annual interest rate used to calculate the borrower's initial cash payment.

Columns.Name: AprBaseInterestRate
Columns.Description: The actual yearly cost of credit stated to the nearest one-fourth of one percent. Any lender subject to the federal Truth-in-Lending Act must fully disclose the APR to the borrower.

Columns.Name: PaymentDiscountInterestRate
Columns.Description: In a payment discount, the lender reduces the first year's interest rate to make the mortgagor more attractive to borrowers.

Columns.Name: InterestRateCap
Columns.Description: A provision of an ARM limiting how much interest rates may increase per adjustment period.

Columns.Name: InterestRateFloor
Columns.Description: For an adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM), the minimum interest rate, as specified in the mortgage note.

Columns.Name: InterestAccrualRate
Columns.Description: The percentage rate at which interest accrues on the mortgage. In most cases, it is also the rate used to calculate the monthly payments, although it is not used for an adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) with payment change limitations.

Columns.Name: InitialInterestRate
Columns.Description: The original interest rate of the mortgage at the time of closing.

Columns.Name: PeriodicRateCap
Columns.Description: A limit on the amount that the interest rate can increase or decrease during any one adjustment period, regardless of how high or low the index might be.

Columns.Name: LifeOfLoanCap
Columns.Description: The maximum interest rate that can be charged during the life of the loan. Also called Lifetime Cap. This value is often expressed as an increment above the initial loan rate. For example, an adjustable rate loan with an initial rate of 7.25% and a 6% lifetime cap will never adjust above a rate of 13.25% (7.25+6.0).

Columns.Name: CapEachAdjustmentPeriodPercentageCap
Columns.Description:
A set percentage amount by which an adjustable rate mortgage may adjust each adjustment period. For adjustable loans, caps are usually quoted as two numbers as in 2/6. The first number indicates how much a loan may adjust at each adjustment period while the second number indicates how much a loan may adjust over its lifetime. 
Loans like the 3/1 and 5/1 adjustable which have an initial fixed period are quoted with 3 numbers as in 3/2/6 which would mean that the first adjustment may be as much as 3%, subsequent adjustments are capped at 2% each, and the lifetime cap is 6%. 
Two-Step loans are quoted with a single cap, which is the amount by which the loan may adjust at its single adjustment date.

Columns.Name: CapSubsequentAdjustmentPeriodPercentageCap
Columns.Description:
A set percentage amount by which an adjustable rate mortgage may adjust each adjustment period. For adjustable loans, caps are usually quoted as two numbers as in 2/6. The first number indicates how much a loan may adjust at each adjustment period while the second number indicates how much a loan may adjust over its lifetime. 
Loans like the 3/1 and 5/1 adjustable which have an initial fixed period are quoted with 3 numbers as in 3/2/6 which would mean that the first adjustment may be as much as 3%, subsequent adjustments are capped at 2% each, and the lifetime cap is 6%. 
Two-Step loans are quoted with a single cap, which is the amount by which the loan may adjust at its single adjustment date.

Columns.Name: CapLifetimeAdjustmentPercentage
Columns.Description:
A set percentage amount by which an adjustable rate mortgage may adjust each adjustment period. For adjustable loans, caps are usually quoted as two numbers as in 2/6. The first number indicates how much a loan may adjust at each adjustment period while the second number indicates how much a loan may adjust over its lifetime. 
Loans like the 3/1 and 5/1 adjustable which have an initial fixed period are quoted with 3 numbers as in 3/2/6 which would mean that the first adjustment may be as much as 3%, subsequent adjustments are capped at 2% each, and the lifetime cap is 6%. 
Two-Step loans are quoted with a single cap, which is the amount by which the loan may adjust at its single adjustment date.

Columns.Name: ArmInterestRateCapAmount
Columns.Description: A provision of an ARM limiting how much the interest rate may increase.

Columns.Name: ArmLifetimeCap
Columns.Description: A provision of an ARM that limits the total increase in interest rates over the life of the loan.

Columns.Name: ArmAdjustmentDate
Columns.Description: The date on which the interest rate changes for an adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM).

Columns.Name: ArmMortgagePaymentCapAmount
Columns.Description: A provision of an ARM limiting how much the mortgage payments may increase.

Columns.Name: ArmChangeFrequency
Columns.Description: The frequency (in months) of payment and/or interest rate changes in an adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM).

Columns.Name: DelinquentLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A loan in which a payment is overdue but not yet in default.

Columns.Name: CreditLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A credit loan is a mortgage that is issued on only the financial strength of a borrower, without great regard for collateral.

Columns.Name: FirstMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A mortgage that has priority over other mortgages.   The mortgage that has first claim in the event of default.

Columns.Name: SecondMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A mortgage that ranks after a first mortgage in priority.  Properties may have two, three, or more mortgages, deeds of trust, or land contracts as liens at the same time.  Legal priority determines the designation first, second, third, etc.

Columns.Name: BalloonLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A mortgage with a balloon payment.

Columns.Name: SecuredLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A loan that is backed by collateral.

Columns.Name: RehabilitationMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A mortgage created to cover the costs of repairing, improving, and sometimes acquiring an existing property.

Columns.Name: UnsecuredLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A loan that is not backed by collateral.

Columns.Name: ConventionalLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A mortgage loan made by an approved lender in which the borrowers ability to repay the debt is not insured by a government agency such as FHA or VA. Normally requires a larger down payment than a government loan.

Columns.Name: AssumableMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A mortgage that can be taken over by the buyer when the house is sold.

Columns.Name: IntermediateTermMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A mortgage loan with a stated maturity at the time of purchase that it is equal to or less than 20 years.

Columns.Name: RollOverLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A loan that /includes a call date earlier than its normal amortization period.

Columns.Name: NoDocLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: Loans made where the lender does not require verification of income. Interest rates are typically higher on these types of loans.

Columns.Name: SubprimeMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: Mortgages that are not conforming mortgages and that are typically made to a person with less than perfect credit, income, or property.

Columns.Name: SecondHomeMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A property that the borrower occupies in addition to his/her principal residence. Rental income from the borrower's second home may not be considered as stable monthly income.

Columns.Name: InsuredMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A mortgage that is protected by the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) or by private mortgage insurance (MI). If the borrower defaults on the loan, the insurer must pay the lender the lesser of the loss incurred or the insured amount

Columns.Name: ConformingMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A loan that conforms to the guidelines established by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac.

Columns.Name: ConstructionLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A short-term loan for funding the cost of construction. The lender advances funds to the builder as the work progresses.

Columns.Name: HomeEquityConversionMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description:
Home Equity Conversion Mortgage (HECM) - 
Also known as the reverse annuity mortgage. This mortgage provides that instead of making payments to a lender, the lender makes payments to the individual. Older homeowners are able to convert home equity into cash this way, in the form of monthly payments. Borrowers don't qualify on the basis of income, but on the value of his or her home. Such a loan does not have to be repaid until the borrower no longer occupies the property.

Columns.Name: ReverseAnnuityMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A system developed for an elderly property owner in which regular monthly payments can be received from a lender. When the total reaches a pre-determined amount, the owner begins repaying the loan or sells the property.

Columns.Name: EquityLoanIndicator
Columns.Description:
A loan based on the borrower's equity in his or her home. Prior to closing; also, an account held by the lender into which a homeowner pays money for taxes and insurance.
(FRM) A mortgage in which the interest rate does not change during the entire term of the loan.

Columns.Name: GraduatedPaymentMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: (GPM) A mortgage where the payments are scheduled to increase, usually annually, for a set number of years, and then level off. GPM can be used with either a fixed or adjustable interest rate, and usually has a 30-year term.

Columns.Name: GrowingEquityMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: (GEM) A fixed rate, graduated payment mortgage with small initial payments that increase each year so that the loan pays off in a shortened term, usually 15 years.

Columns.Name: FullyAmortizedArmIndicator
Columns.Description: An adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) with a monthly payment that is sufficient to amortize the remaining balance, at the interest accrual rate, over the amortization term.

Columns.Name: FixedRateMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: (FRM) A mortgage in which the interest rate does not change during the entire term of the loan.

Columns.Name: AdjustableMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: Any mortgage that does not have a fixed interest rate and a fixed payment for the term of the loan, or does not amortize to zero at the end of the set term, when required payments are made on time.

Columns.Name: ConvertibleArmIndicator
Columns.Description: An adjustable-rate mortgage that can be converted to a fixed-rate mortgage under specified conditions.

Columns.Name: WraparoundMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A method of acquiring additional financing on real estate by placing the additional funds in a secondary or junior position to the existing debt. As its name implies, a wraparound mortgage 'wraps around' an existing first mortgage. This method of obtaining additional capital is often used with commercial property where there is substantial equity in the property and where the existing first mortgage has an attractive low interest rate. By obtaining a wraparound, the borrower receives dollars based on the difference between current market value of the property and the outstanding balance on the first mortgage. The borrower amortizes the wraparound mortgage which now includes the balance of the first mortgage and the wraparound lender forwards the necessary periodic debt service to the holder of the first mortgage. Thus, the borrower reduces the equity and at the same time obtains an interest rate lower than would be possible through a normal second mortgage. The lender receives the leverage resulting from an interest rate on the wraparound greater than the interest paid to the holder of the first mortgage.

Columns.Name: NoCostLoanIndicator
Columns.Description: A no-cost loan can either be: 1) a loan that has no "lender costs" associated with it or, 2) a loan that also covers purchases or refinancing costs, which may be incurred in buying a home, obtaining and/or refinancing a loan, but are not directly charged by the lender. The interest rate on this type of loan is higher.

Columns.Name: TwoStepMortgageIndicator
Columns.Description: A loan where the interest rate is fixed for the first seven years and then is adjusted one time for the balance of the loan period.

Columns.Name: PropertyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Property.

Columns.Name: MortgageLoanTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Mortgage Loan Type.

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Legal priority determines the designation first, second, third, etc.","isNullable":true,"name":"SecondMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"BalloonLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A mortgage with a balloon payment.","isNullable":true,"name":"BalloonLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"SecuredLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A loan that is backed by collateral.","isNullable":true,"name":"SecuredLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"RehabilitationMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A mortgage created to cover the costs of repairing, improving, and sometimes acquiring an existing property.","isNullable":true,"name":"RehabilitationMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"UnsecuredLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A loan that is not backed by collateral.","isNullable":true,"name":"UnsecuredLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"ConventionalLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A mortgage loan made by an approved lender in which the borrowers ability to repay the debt is not insured by a government agency such as FHA or VA. Normally requires a larger down payment than a government loan.","isNullable":true,"name":"ConventionalLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"AssumableMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A mortgage that can be taken over by the buyer when the house is sold.","isNullable":true,"name":"AssumableMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"IntermediateTermMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A mortgage loan with a stated maturity at the time of purchase that it is equal to or less than 20 years.","isNullable":true,"name":"IntermediateTermMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"RollOverLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A loan that /includes a call date earlier than its normal amortization period.","isNullable":true,"name":"RollOverLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"NoDocLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Loans made where the lender does not require verification of income. Interest rates are typically higher on these types of loans.","isNullable":true,"name":"NoDocLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"SubprimeMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Mortgages that are not conforming mortgages and that are typically made to a person with less than perfect credit, income, or property.","isNullable":true,"name":"SubprimeMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"SecondHomeMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A property that the borrower occupies in addition to his/her principal residence. Rental income from the borrower's second home may not be considered as stable monthly income.","isNullable":true,"name":"SecondHomeMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"InsuredMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A mortgage that is protected by the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) or by private mortgage insurance (MI). If the borrower defaults on the loan, the insurer must pay the lender the lesser of the loss incurred or the insured amount","isNullable":true,"name":"InsuredMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"ConformingMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A loan that conforms to the guidelines established by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac.","isNullable":true,"name":"ConformingMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"ConstructionLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A short-term loan for funding the cost of construction. The lender advances funds to the builder as the work progresses.","isNullable":true,"name":"ConstructionLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"HomeEquityConversionMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Home Equity Conversion Mortgage (HECM) - 
Also known as the reverse annuity mortgage. This mortgage provides that instead of making payments to a lender, the lender makes payments to the individual. Older homeowners are able to convert home equity into cash this way, in the form of monthly payments. Borrowers don't qualify on the basis of income, but on the value of his or her home. Such a loan does not have to be repaid until the borrower no longer occupies the property.","isNullable":true,"name":"HomeEquityConversionMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"ReverseAnnuityMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A system developed for an elderly property owner in which regular monthly payments can be received from a lender. When the total reaches a pre-determined amount, the owner begins repaying the loan or sells the property.","isNullable":true,"name":"ReverseAnnuityMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"EquityLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A loan based on the borrower's equity in his or her home. Prior to closing; also, an account held by the lender into which a homeowner pays money for taxes and insurance.
(FRM) A mortgage in which the interest rate does not change during the entire term of the loan.","isNullable":true,"name":"EquityLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"GraduatedPaymentMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"(GPM) A mortgage where the payments are scheduled to increase, usually annually, for a set number of years, and then level off. GPM can be used with either a fixed or adjustable interest rate, and usually has a 30-year term.","isNullable":true,"name":"GraduatedPaymentMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"GrowingEquityMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"(GEM) A fixed rate, graduated payment mortgage with small initial payments that increase each year so that the loan pays off in a shortened term, usually 15 years.","isNullable":true,"name":"GrowingEquityMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"FullyAmortizedArmIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"An adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) with a monthly payment that is sufficient to amortize the remaining balance, at the interest accrual rate, over the amortization term.","isNullable":true,"name":"FullyAmortizedArmIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"FixedRateMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"(FRM) A mortgage in which the interest rate does not change during the entire term of the loan.","isNullable":true,"name":"FixedRateMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"AdjustableMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Any mortgage that does not have a fixed interest rate and a fixed payment for the term of the loan, or does not amortize to zero at the end of the set term, when required payments are made on time.","isNullable":true,"name":"AdjustableMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"ConvertibleArmIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"An adjustable-rate mortgage that can be converted to a fixed-rate mortgage under specified conditions.","isNullable":true,"name":"ConvertibleArmIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"WraparoundMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A method of acquiring additional financing on real estate by placing the additional funds in a secondary or junior position to the existing debt. As its name implies, a wraparound mortgage 'wraps around' an existing first mortgage. This method of obtaining additional capital is often used with commercial property where there is substantial equity in the property and where the existing first mortgage has an attractive low interest rate. By obtaining a wraparound, the borrower receives dollars based on the difference between current market value of the property and the outstanding balance on the first mortgage. The borrower amortizes the wraparound mortgage which now includes the balance of the first mortgage and the wraparound lender forwards the necessary periodic debt service to the holder of the first mortgage. Thus, the borrower reduces the equity and at the same time obtains an interest rate lower than would be possible through a normal second mortgage. The lender receives the leverage resulting from an interest rate on the wraparound greater than the interest paid to the holder of the first mortgage.","isNullable":true,"name":"WraparoundMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"NoCostLoanIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A no-cost loan can either be: 1) a loan that has no "lender costs" associated with it or, 2) a loan that also covers purchases or refinancing costs, which may be incurred in buying a home, obtaining and/or refinancing a loan, but are not directly charged by the lender. The interest rate on this type of loan is higher.","isNullable":true,"name":"NoCostLoanIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"TwoStepMortgageIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A loan where the interest rate is fixed for the first seven years and then is adjusted one time for the balance of the loan period.","isNullable":true,"name":"TwoStepMortgageIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"PropertyId"},"dataType":"long","description":"The unique identifier of a Property.","isNullable":true,"name":"PropertyId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"MortgageLoanTypeId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of a Mortgage Loan Type.","isNullable":true,"name":"MortgageLoanTypeId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"MortgageLoanSummary.cdm.json/MortgageLoanSummary","name":"CustomerId"},"dataType":"long","description":"The unique identifier of a Customer.","isNullable":true,"name":"CustomerId"}]}}}
Properties.Description:
A legal document that pledges property to a creditor for the repayment of the loan, and is the term used to describe the loan itself. 

Some states use the term First Trust Deeds to refer to mortgage loans.
